awd_titl_txt: Representations, Cohomology, and Geometry in Tensor Triangulated Categories
awd_abstract_narration:
Representation theory emerged over 100 years ago with the pioneering work of Frobenius and Schur. A representation is a realization of an algebraic structure (i.e., a group, Lie algebra, quantum group, or Lie superalgebra) by matrices. Such realizations have been successfully applied to provide deep insights into these complicated algebraic objects. Over the course of the last century, representation theory has emerged as a central area of modern mathematics with connections to combinatorics, algebraic geometry, topology, number theory, along with applications to physics. More recent developments have included using the representation theory of Lie groups to better understand signal processing and the translation of the P versus NP problem in computer science via geometric complexity theory into questions about decomposing representations for the general linear group. 

The PI will investigate the representation theory of algebraic groups, Lie algebras, and Lie superalgebras via categorical and geometric methods. In recent years, these algebro-geometric methods have played a predominant role in understanding the relationships between representations in various algebraic categories. Cohomological methods will be used to answer questions about the characters and existence of filtrations for representations. Geometric constructions and cohomology in triangulated categories will be employed to analyze the behavior of the representations for the aforementioned algebraic objects. The PI will also determine the relationship between a tensor triangulated category and its underlying categorical spectrum.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits:

The Principal Investigator (PI) aimed to apply homological and geometric methods to solve central problems in the representation theory of algebraic groups, Lie algebras and quantum groups. Often times invariants such as homology or cohomology provide a bridge to reveal underlying geometric structures. This is evident with the ideas encompassing the use and computation of the Balmer spectrum and tensor triangular geometry.

Significant progress was made in terms of understanding representations of a reductive algebraic group, G.

1)     The PI (with Hardesty and Sobaje) answered an important open question raised by Friedlander by proving necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of non-injective mock injective G-modules.

2)     The PI (with Garibaldi and Guralnick) proved Gross' Conjecture that provided necessary and sufficient conditions for the absolute irreducibility of a Weyl module for G.

3)     The PI (with Bendel, Pillen and Sobaje) constructed a counterexample to Donkin’s Tilting Module Conjecture (open for 30 years), in addition to a counterexample to Jantzen’s Question about p-filtration for Weyl modules (open for 40 years).

4)     The PI (with Grodal, Carlson and Mazza) computed the ranks of the endotrivial groups for finite groups of Lie type over arbitrary characteristics.

The theory for Lie superalgebras was further developed by the PI and his coauthors.

5)     The PI (with D. Grantcharov, N. Grantcharov and Wu) introduced a new class of parabolic subalgebras that have good cohomological properties governed by the classical Bott-Borel-Weil theorem. These results were later used to verify a 10 year old conjecture given by Boe, Kujawa and the PI pertaining to the identification of support varieties for classical simple Lie superalgebras.

6)     The  PI (with Jenkins) introduced and studied a natural analog for the nilpotent cone for classical simple Lie superalgebras.

The PI also made new discoveries involving the representations of Schur algebra and Hecke algebras.

7)     For Hecke algebras of type B/C, the PI (with Lai and Xiang) concretely described its 1-faithful quasi-hereditary cover (as defined by Rouquier) by constructing  natural Schur algebras (for type B/C) via coideal subalgebras.

8)     The PI (with Xiang) developed a theory of support varieties which detects natural homological properties such as the complexity of modules for Iwahori Hecke algebras of type A. The theory entailed a canonical description in an affine space where computations are tractable. Such realizations were not available from earlier work using Hochschild cohomology.

Tensor triangular geometry as defined by Balmer is a powerful method to extract the ambient geometry from a given tensor triangulated category.

9)     The PI (with Boe and Kujawa) provided criteria on support data to classify thick tensor ideals and the Balmer spectrum for a compactly generated tensor triangulated category. These results were applied to classify thick tensor ideals and compute the Balmer spectrum for the general linear Lie superalgebra over the complex numbers.

10)  The PI (with Vashaw and Yakimov) introduced a non-commutative tensor triangular geometry called monoidal triangular geometry (MTG). This entailed the use of prime and completely prime ideals. The MTG was effectively used to establish important results about the tensor product property for support maps.

 

Broader Impacts:

The PI's research program emphasizes the professional training of graduate students and postdocs. During the grant period (2017-23), the PI graduated four Ph.D students, and is currently advising two Ph.D students. The PI also served as the Postdoctoral Research Mentor for two postdocs, and the Postdoctoral Teaching Mentor for two other postdocs. The PI promoted vertically integrated activities within the framework of this training program. For example, the PI co-organized the Algebra Seminar with the research postdocs in the group, and he coordinated research collaborations between the PI, postdocs and graduate students.

On the national and international level, the PI organized workshops aimed at the professional development of junior mathematicians. The PI was a main organizer for the NSF funded Southeastern Lie Theory Workshop Series. Since its inception in 2009, a research workshop has been held each year at a major research university in the Southeastern US. During the grant, the PI also organized five AMS Special Sessions, three conferences and one NSF RTG Grant Summer School held at the University of Georgia in 2018.

The PI constructed a YouTube channel with resources that involve talks on important research trends in algebra and representation theory. Furthermore, the PI's personal website and the SE Lie Theory Workshop webpages provide resources for the dissemination of information to mathematical community.
